The SPEAKER ( Hon.
Milton Dick ) took the chair at 10:00, made an acknowledgement of country and read prayers.
COMMITTEES
Petitions Committee
Report
Ms TEMPLEMAN (Macquarie) (10:01): I present the 23rd report of the Petitions Committee for the 47th Parliament.
Chair Ms Susan Templeman MP
Deputy Chair Mr Ross Vasta MP
Mr Sam Birrell MP
Ms Alison Byrnes MP
Ms Lisa Chesters MP
Mr Garth Hamilton MP
Ms Tracey Roberts MP
Ms Meryl Swanson MP
This committee is supported by staff of the Department of the House of Representatives

span.span: Report summarising the petitions and ministerial responses being presented.
The committee met in private session in the 47th Parliament on 07 February 2024, 14 February 2024 and 28 February 2024.
1. The committee resolved to present the following 41 petitions in accordance with standing order 207:

PETITIONS
Presentation
Ms TEMPLEMAN (Macquarie) (10:01): I present the following 41 petitions:
National Disability Insurance Scheme

The NDIS was intended to provide support for people based on their individual support needs, not their diagnosis. Complex cases of ADHD meet the criteria in the NDIS Act, but the fact that ADHD is not included in the NDIA's lists of conditions for eligibility undermines the goals of the NDIS Act. ADHD does not affect people in the same way. Similar to Autism, there are different levels of functional impairment that affect the everyday challenges a person living with ADHD experiences. ADHD is a lifelong condition; where a person clearly meets the NDIS criteria, they should be able to access reasonable and necessary supports under the NDIS.
We therefore ask the House to should allow people with ADHD who meet the disability requirements of the NDIS Act to access the NDIS.
from 58 citizens (Petition No. EN5855)
Business Innovation and Investment Program

We urgently petition the Australian Parliament to address the prolonged processing delays in the BIIP, particularly in the Provisional stage. According to FOI Request FA 22/11/00681, more than 20,000 provisional business visas subclass 188 have been awaiting to be processed as at 30/06/2022. Additionally, The Migration Review Strategy 2023 confirmed the Government will not provide any new allocations for the provisional BIIP visa, which means no 188 applications could be processed in FY 2023-24. The visa applicants would be enduring a minimum of 36-month wait by 30/06/2024 with no end in sight. There are visa applications lodged around 05/2021 but still have not been finalised yet, whilst at the time of their application, the indicative processing time was around 12-20 months. This uncertainty has a profound impact on applicants and influences the future trajectory of their families and children.

We therefore ask the House to urge the Government to review the processing time for the BIIP and allocate substantial quotas for the 2024-25 FY, to expedite the resolution to clear the backlog of BIIP Provisional visa subclass 188 applications. By doing so, the Government will extend a fair and reasonable response to those investors who have been patiently awaiting processing. They are eager to come to Australia and committed to embarking on long-planned business ventures. Facilitating their timely entry will not only alleviate the backlog but also empower them to contribute meaningfully to Australia's economic landscape, thereby fostering the nation's prosperity.
from 520 citizens (Petition No. EN5856)
Environmental Defenders Office

We therefore ask the House to defund the Environmental Defenders Office because the Federal Court has found them to be dishonest in how they conduct themselves in pursuing their interests and not in the interests of all Australians. This radical organisation will help deter investment in Australia, leading to higher energy and overall costs. They do not care about the interests of all Australians but rather for them to meet own personal interests.

We therefore ask the House to defund the Environmental Defenders Office because the Federal Court has found them to be dishonest in how they conduct themselves in pursuing their interests and not in the interests of all Australians. This radical organisation will help deter investment in Australia, leading to higher energy and overall costs. They do not care about the interests of all Australians but rather for them to meet own personal interests.
from seven citizens (Petition No. EN5857)
Climate Change

The fate of our planet is at a critical juncture, highlighted by the IPCC's final Synthesis Report and the "Global Crisis. There is a Way Out" forum. Current trends project a catastrophic global warming of over 1.5 degrees Celsius, signalling irreversible damage to vital environmental systems. Concurrently, an international group of volunteers, including scientists, has forewarned of an impending global cataclysm by 2036. Australia, as the world's third-largest exporter of carbon emissions, plays a pivotal role in combating this crisis. Despite 80% of Australians recognising the impacts of climate change and 83% supporting the closure of coal-fired power stations, the government continues to approve new coal and gas projects. This action contradicts Australia's international obligations and the urgent need for drastic emission reductions.
We therefore ask the House to Immediately halt the approval of new coal and gas projects, aligning with Australia's commitments under International Law.
from 25 citizens (Petition No. EN5858)
Taxation
NO THRESHOLDS FOR UNDER AGE OF 65

YOU BORROW MONEY FROM A BANK OR A FINACIAL INSITUTION THE BORROWER HAS TO PAY THEIR DEBTS AS SOON AS THEY GET THEIR GOOD/SERVICES SO THEN WHAT IS THE DIFFERNECE BY THESE AUSTRALIANS UNDER 65 WHO ARE NOT RETIRED
NO THRESHOLDS FOR UNDER AGE OF 65

ALL AUSTRALIANS WHO EARN ANY AMOUNT OF MONEY (EXCEPT THE AGED PENSIONERS) TO PAY THEIR TAX! NO MORE THRESHOLD INCOME OF $18,000 & TO BE ALLOWED TO COLLECT THNE ALL THE JOBKEEPER/NDIS & ALL THE OFFENSIVE ASSISTANCES
ALL UNIVERSITY STUDENT DEBT TO BE PAID, NO MORE THRESHOLD OF $ $48,000+
We therefore ask the House to REMOVE ALL THRESHOLDS FOR UNDER AGE OF 65 NOT RETIRED.

ALL AUSTRALIANS WHO EARN ANY AMOUNT OF MONEY (EXCEPT THE AGED PENSIONERS) TO PAY THEIR TAX! NO MORE THRESHOLD INCOME OF $18,000+ & TO BE ALLOWED TO COLLECT THNE ALL THE JOBKEEPER/NDIS & ALL THE OFFENSIVE ASSISTANCES
ALL UNIVERSITY STUDENT DEBT TO BE PAID, NO MORE INCOME THRESHOLD OF $48,000+
from two citizens (Petition No. EN5860)
Pensions and Benefits
WHY SHOULD TAX PAYERS SUBSIDIZE JOBKEEER/NDIS AUSTRALIANS OR EVEN ALL ASYLUMSEEKRS/ILLIGALS
THEIR RENT. PHONE, ENERGY, INTERNET, & MUST MANDATE TO PAY THEIR MEIDCARE ELVY NOW
WHY SHOULD TAX PAYERS PAY FOR THEIR FREE MEDICAL OR HOSPITALS OR MEIDCATIONS
We therefore ask the House to REMOVE ALL ASISTANCES TO JOBKEEPER/NDIS/ASYLUM SEEKERS/ILLIGALS
ALL MUST PAY THEIR MEDICARE LEVY NOW
from two citizens (Petition No. EN5861)
International Humanitarian Assistance
WHYY SHOULD AUSTRALIANS FUND ALL THESE FOREING COUNTRIES OR UNITED NATIONS, W.H.O. & MANY OTHERS WHILE WE HAVE HUGE CRISIS IN AUSTRALIA TO MANY AUSTRALIAN CITIZANS!
WE DEMAND FIX OUR COUNTRIES PROBLEMS NOW NOT THE FOREIGN FIRST!
We therefore ask the House to STOP ALL FOREIGN AID OF $4.77 billion UNITL THE AUSTRALIAN COUNTRIES PROBLEMS ARE FIXED NOW!
WE DEMAND TO STOP WASTING OUR TAX MAONEY ON FOREINGERS!
WE AUSTRALIAN CISTIZAN/BUSINESSES COME FIRST!
from 19 citizens (Petition No. EN5862)
Nuclear Energy

The U.S. has now laid out its international strategy to commercialize nuclear fusion power at the UN climate summit in Dubai, U.S. Special Envoy on Climate Change John Kerry said. "Fusion could have an important advantage over today's nuclear fission plants that split atoms, as it does not produce long-lasting radioactive waste. If deployed successfully, it could also provide a cheap source of carbon-free electricity."

We therefore ask the House to licence under SECT 140A of the ENVIRONMENT PROTECTION AND BIODIVERSITY CONSERVATION ACT 1999, and any other legislation requiring the licencing of the use of fusion energy and developing and building of fusion power plants for study and commercialization and retain the prohibition on nuclear fission energy. Instigate a committee of international nuclear lawyers to review laws.

Join the US, Can, UK, and EU in acknowledging fusion and joining in developing and commercializing fusion energy and industry and developing its other uses in Australia outside the fission regulations.
from three citizens (Petition No. EN5867)
Health Care
We are asking for diagnostic testing and consults, as well as all healthcare, to become more affordable and accessible for all ages.
It costs outrageous amounts of money just to be diagnosed with cancer or another illness if you do not have a concession card.
It cost nearly $1,000 just to diagnose the lumps in my breasts as fibroadenomas and that's because I am a student, if I were not a student it would have cost even more.
We therefore ask the House to create accessible and affordable women's health clinics including Breast Screen clinics for those of all ages not just those over a certain age bracket.
from 14 citizens (Petition No. EN5869)
World Health Organization

The WHO is an unelected body that the Government continues to work to strengthen its authority and autonomy. The pandemic treaty scheduled to be adopted in May 2024 hasn't been given discussion or consent of the senate or public before signing and would make this a legally binding treaty. The treaty and the IHR amendments along with the UN political declaration on pandemic prevention preparedness and response are made to work together to create a global health security architecture. The troubling provisions are that it preempts other international agreements, removes liability from vaccines on global level, expands unilateral authority to the WHO, removes the requirement to verify an emergency with a state before making a declaration, the WHO would have a say in how we spend our money, would have the authority to create protocols and rules and determine consequences for not following agreements. We would lose the ability to choose our own health actions as demonstrated by having to follow the IHR regulations during covid rather than our own pandemic plan. The WHO, UN, WEF are controlled by unelected people whose motives are not in our interests but for elite's interests of power, money and control.

We therefore ask the House to review carefully what this pandemic treaty means for our personal freedoms. To ask who does this serve? The House also needs to ask does belonging to these groups of the WEF, WHO and UN help us as a country or hinder us. Exit the WHO!
from 43 citizens (Petition No. EN5871)
Global Security

In an era marked by escalating global conflicts and wars, the need for dedicated efforts towards peace and conflict resolution has never been more critical. The continuous growth of international tensions not only threatens the stability of nations but also undermines the collective efforts towards addressing global challenges such as climate change, poverty, and disease. The establishment of a dedicated peace-seeking arm of government, spearheaded by a Minister for Peace, would signify a profound commitment to proactive peacebuilding, diplomatic engagement, and the prevention of conflict. This initiative would serve as a beacon of hope and leadership, inspiring other nations to prioritise peace and diplomacy over aggression and conflict.

We therefore ask the House to Establish a dedicated peace-seeking branch within the government, focused solely on developing strategies, policies, and initiatives that promote global peace and conflict resolution.
Appoint a Minister for Peace, responsible for leading this branch, coordinating with international bodies, and fostering diplomatic relations aimed at conflict prevention and resolution.
from nine citizens (Petition No. EN5874)
World Health Organization
Australian Citizens "Stop the WHO Pandemic Treaty" .
We therefore ask the House to vote "NO" to the WHO Pandemic Treaty
from 52 citizens (Petition No. EN5878)
Public Broadcasting
WHY SHOULD TAX PAYERS KEEP SUBSIDIZNG THESE ENETILED MEDIA WHO REFUSE TO ABIDE BY THEIR CHARTER & NO BIAS OF ONLY LEFT WING
THERE IS NO DIVERSITY OF PEOPLE/THOUGHT/BELIEF ALLOWED!
TO ALLOW RACISM, HATE, DIVISION & LIES TO BE BROADCAST IS INTRABLE ANYMORE

WITH NO HEAD OF THE ABC/SBS/NITV TAKING ACTION AGAINST THIS & THEN OUR FEDERAL GOVERNEMENT TO KEEP ALLOWING THIS BIAS TO KEEP INCREASING & THERE IS NO CONSECUNCES THEN THEY HAVE NO RIGHT TO BE FUNDED BY TAX PAYERS WHO REFUSE TO GIVE THEIR MONEY!
We therefore ask the House to STOP ALL FUNDING TO ABC/SBS/NITV & TO BE SUBSCRIPTION WHO EVER WANTS IT OR TO SHUT OFF THE ABC/S/S/NITV! SELL IT OFF NOW
IF THE GOVERNEMENT REFUSES TO STOP FUNDING THIS BIASED TAX PAYER OVER FUNDED MEDIA, THEN ALL TAX PAYERS OF AUSTRALIA HAVE A RIGHT TO GET A TAX DEDUDCTION/REFUND
WE DEMAND EQUALITY OF VOICE
from 10 citizens (Petition No. EN5879)
Medicare
WHY SHOULD ALL TAXPAYERS SUBSIDIED SOMEONES FREE HEALTH CARE
EVERYONE IN AUSTRALIA MUST AY THEIR MEIDCARE LEVY (EXCEPT THE AGED PENSIONES & FULL TIME AUSTRALIAN STUDENTS TO 25)
THERE IS A CRISIS IN MEDCARE & WE ALL HAVE TO SUFFER BECAUSE MANY UNDER THE NDIS, JOBKEEER, ILLIGALS, PRISONERS & LOW INCOME PEOPLE PAY NOTHING TO THE HEALTH SYSTEM?
We therefore ask the House to MANADE ALL AUSTRALIANS PAY THEIR MEDICARE LEVY BUT EXEMPT THE AGED PENSIONERS & FULL TIME AUSTRALIAN STUNENTS TO 25
from four citizens (Petition No. EN5880)
Fuel Excise

ALL TAX PAYERS WHO USE PETROL FOR THEIR BUSIENSSES, WORK, TRAVELL ARE PROPPING UP THE WELFARE OF THIS COUNTRY & OUR GOVERNEMENTS CONTINUALLY INCREAS THIS UNFAIR TAX ON TO OWNERS OF VEHICLES USING PETROL BUT NT ONTO ELECTRIC CRS, E-NBIKE RIDERS OR CYSLISTS WHO PAY NOTHING ie CYCLISTS, E-BIKE RIDERS ARE USING OUR ROADS BUT ARE NOT TO BE LICENCED, PAY NO REGISTRATION & NO PETROL EXCIES WHICH IS USED TO FIX OUR ROADS! TO PENILZE ONE SET ASTRALIANS IS DISCRMINATORY. HOW IS THAT GOOD FOR THE COUNTRY UNDER THE AUST. CONSTITUTION FOR OUR GOVERNEMENT TO KEEP PEACE & FIRNESS FOR ALL
We therefore ask the House to REMOVE ALL PETROL EXCISE
THIS IS EQUALITY IN SERVICE FOR USING THE ROADS OF AUSTRALIA!
from 10 citizens (Petition No. EN5881)
Foreign Investment
To many foreign investors in Australia own farms and businesses and manipulate the prices at shops this needs to change
We therefore ask the House to investigate foreign ownership of farms and businesses in Australia and their control over prices of food and land value in Australia
from six citizens (Petition No. EN5883)
Parliamentarians' Entitlements
IS A PRIME MINSTER RETIRES WHY ARE WE SUBSIDIZING THEIR PERKS OUT OF PARLIAMENTS!
IF A RETIRE DO I GET ANY PERKS PAID BY TAX PAYERS?
NO I DO NOT SO WHT ARE THEY WE HAVE SO MANY OTHER MORE IMPOERTANT THINGS TO PAY FOR AS AGED CARE!
We therefore ask the House to TO REMOVE ALL EX. PRIME MINSTERS PERKS NOW!
from 22 citizens (Petition No. EN5884)
Australia Day
Lately, Australia Day has been the subject of a national debate among Australians.
But what if we could find a way to celebrate that unites all Australians, regardless of their stance on the matter?
Here's the idea: What if we could celebrate Australia Day over three days, representing Australia's past, present, and future?

The 26th, representing the past, would be the recognition date for mourning and acknowledging the dark past of Australia's history for Australia's First Nations people and also symbolise a national soliloquy of apology to Indigenous persons and communities, past and present, who have lost their lives under unfair circumstances or suffered from injustice and discrimination.

The 27th, representing the present, would celebrate Indigenous culture, accomplishments, and entertainment. The day will feature cultural performances, Dreamtime Stories, food stalls, art and fashion shows, and more. The 27th would exclusively promote and showcase Indigenous talents and their achievements.
The 28th, representing the future, would celebrate all Australians of all generations, nationalities and backgrounds.
And all events, celebrations and activities usually held on January 26th in the past would instead be celebrated on January 28th.

By considering all views of all Australians, we could foster respect and unity without any controversy. This way, Australia Day would no longer be a contentious issue but rather a celebration that brings us all together.

We therefore ask the House to consider making a change in the current system to create a unified holiday that can accommodate every Australian, quell division, and foster harmony and coexistence in our nation.
from 14 citizens (Petition No. EN5885)
Telecommunications

Melonba is a growing suburb adjacent to Marsden Park. Since it's inception, Melonba has receiving poor mobile coverage which is impacting on local residents ability to communicate over the cellular network. Phone calls are unable to be made or received and residents are relying on "wi-fi calling" to make and receive phone calls. The major telecommunications companies claim that mobile coverage is a "commercial decision", however, in light of the Optus outage, it potentially puts residents in the position where they can not contact emergency services. This is an unacceptable position.
We therefore ask the House to refer this issue to a House Committee to investigate and report back on the issue and to invest funds in improving the quality of mobile coverage in the Melonba area.
from 22 citizens (Petition No. EN5886)
Lipoedema

Lipoedema is an accumulation of diseased fat and is driven by hormonal event often starting at puberty. Around 11% of women are impacted by the disease demonstrating the requirement of urgent recognition by medicare Australia.
1.Lipoedema defies conventional treatments making diet and exercise ineffective treatments.
2. Heaviness, severe pain, swelling, immobility, and a diminished quality of life demand recognition for medical coverage.
3. Loss of leg and arm architecture not only alters a person's gait but also intensified pain and strain on the body.
4. Recognise the perilous nature of exercising with advanced stages of Lipoedema which may lead to fractures, deep vein thrombosis, and clots.

5. Acknowledge that the progression of lipoedema can lead to the fibrosis of the lymphatics, and co-morbities such as secondary obesity and varicose veins, emphasing the need to urgent medical coverage and early intervention.
6. Highlight the mental strain associated with lipoedema, including anxiety, depression, eating disorders and in cases, tragically suicide.
7. Progression of lipoedema leads to limited treatment options in late stages and increased damage to the lymphatic system.
8. Recognition of the financial stress, work loss, and compromised quality of life resulting from pain and immobility.
9. Recognise the discomfort and embarrassment associated with lipoedema emphasising the importance of medical coverage to address both the physical and emotional aspects of the condition.
We therefore ask the House to officially recognise lipoedema as a progressive, chronic and debilitating disease, advocating for medicare coverage and early intervention for affected individuals.
from 883 citizens (Petition No. EN5889)
Middle East

While thanking the Australian government for its aid and humanitarian assistance in Palestine, we ask that it take further steps to support the safety, human rights and self-determination of the Palestinian people.
We therefore ask the House to call upon the Australian government to:
• Actively advocate for an immediate ceasefire in Gaza, a halt to attacks in the occupied territories of the West Bank and the deployment of an international peace keeping force;
• Call for the release of all hostages and political prisoners in Israel and Palestine;
• and formally recognise the Palestine in accordance with the 2023 Australian Labor Party's Platform policy.
from 468 citizens (Petition No. EN5890)
Superannuation

DFRDB military superannuation schemes are deemed as "untaxed". Military superannuation pensions paid to beneficiaries are therefore taxable in the hands of each beneficiary. The Commonwealth's taxation treatment of military superannuation schemes is wrong in principle and in practice, to the point of discriminating against members and former members of the Australian Defence Force.Australian pensioners funding their retirement from accumulation (defined contributions) pension funds are deemed to have been members of "taxed" schemes. Their superannuation pension is tax free Members of the ADF were and are compelled to contribute to their military superannuation scheme from their gross (pre-tax) salary. DFRDB contributors compulsorily paid 5.5%.
We therefore ask the House to consider the request to remove taxation for. recipients of this fund
from four citizens (Petition No. EN5891)
Varghese, Mr George

George Varghese, a 32 year old Melbourne resident originally from India, faces the possibility of deportation following a tragic incident that happened in November 2022. George Varghese's car was involved in a collision with a pedestrian, resulting in the pedestrian's unfortunate passing. Despite George Varghese's driving not contributing to the accident, he was charged with failing to stop and render assistance, leading to a 12 month imprisonment term and the cancellation of his spouse visa. He now faces the distressing possibility of deportation.

His wife, who is an Australian citizen of Indian heritage and has lived in Australia since the age of 9, and is a Medical Practitioner, is also at risk of being forced to return to India. This could have far reaching consequences for her and for the extensive network of family and friends they have built in Australia. We request our community to show compassion and support for George Varghese's plea to avoid deportation. Your signature on this petition contributes to our collective effort and to find a just and compassionate solution for him and his wife. By signing this petition, it will be submitted to the authorities supporting the revocation of George Varghese's Visa cancellation once he has served a 12 month imprisonment term.
We therefore ask the House to to revoke the cancellation of George Varghese's visa.
from 3,831 citizens (Petition No. EN5893)

subdebateinfo.title: E-Cigarettes, Vaping Products and Tobacco Regulation

p.span: E-Cigarettes, Vaping Products and Tobacco Regulation

People who smoke and Vape need to be heard. This is not a communist dictatorship. We live in a democratic country and we don't want to be restricted. First it was the high tax on cigarettes making the prices sky rocket for years and now that smokers have started to vape because of affordability you want to ban it without a vote or any say from us. This is NOT FAIR.
We therefore ask the House to lift the ban on vapes (including nicotine) or drop the prices for cigarettes and have no tax on tobacco.
from 152 citizens (Petition No. EN5894)

subdebateinfo.title: Centenary of Women's Suffrage Commemorative Fountain

p.span: Centenary of Women's Suffrage Commemorative Fountain

The Centenary of Women Suffrage Fountain in Canberra, last updated in 2010, currently does not reflect the significant advancements in women's political participation and representation in the Australian federal parliament adequately. Since its last update, we have witnessed numerous historical milestones, including the election of Nova Peris as the first Indigenous female member of parliament, Anne Aly as Australia's first Muslim female federal politician, and Julie Bishop as the first female Foreign Minister of Australia, among several others.

Additionally, while some firsts have been recognised on the fountain, others are notably and strangely absent. These include Penny Wong's groundbreaking role as the first openly lesbian cabinet minister and the first Asian Australian female parliamentarian.

Furthermore, the fountain currently honours only the women who ran in the 1903 election, omitting those who ran between 1903 and 1943, despite their crucial contributions to our political landscape. This exclusion gives the impression that nothing noteworthy occurred during those years when, in fact, many women were actively participating in politics.

We therefore ask the House to amend, update, and expand the Centenary of Women Suffrage Fountain to include and honour all these significant figures and milestones. This update will ensure the fountain truly reflects Australia's diverse and inclusive history of women's suffrage and political representation. It will serve as a beacon of inspiration and education for current and future generations, highlighting the crucial role women have played in shaping our nation's parliamentary landscape.
from 406 citizens (Petition No. EN5895)
Surf Lifesaving
Surf life saving receives no government funding, relying on donations. They save thousands of lives each year in Australia
We therefore ask the House to contribute government funding towards surf life saving as without them and donations there would be no one on our beaches to make them safe.
from 10 citizens (Petition No. EN5897)
Capital Gains Tax

Australia currently has a massive housing supply shortage with people on the average wage unable to afford either buying or renting in all capital cities and many regional areas. Many thousand upon thousands of houses are locked into investments by the so called 'baby boomers' and they will not put these residences up for sale until retirement to evade the capital gains tax. The upshot is that these thousands of properties will not be put onto the market for some years and when they do, they will be exempt from capital gains anyhow.

We therefore ask the House to have a moratorium on residential property capital gains to encourage many thousands of houses be offered into the housing market many years earlier than would otherwise be the case. The government will not lose capital gains tax revenue as baby boomers are only going to sell the properties once retired and cancel out that tax component anyhow.
from five citizens (Petition No. EN5898)
International Humanitarian Assistance: Gaza

The ICJ believe it is plausible that a genocide is being perpetrated against the Palestinians in Gaza. The people of Gaza need aid now more than ever before. With Australia's withdrawal of aid to UNRWA it could be considered Australia is complicit in this genocide.
We therefore ask the House to reinstate funding to the UNRWA.
from 3,564 citizens (Petition No. EN5899)

subdebateinfo.title: International Humanitarian Assistance: Occupied Palestinian Territories

p.span: International Humanitarian Assistance: Occupied Palestinian Territories

As concerned citizens, we call upon the Australian Parliament to immediately cease its funding of the United Nations Relief and Works Agency (UNRWA), given the Agency's demonstrated lack of will or capability to ensure neutrality in its textbooks.

Australia cannot, in good faith, continue to fund this organisation until systemic and urgently needed reforms are developed and implemented to eliminate hateful content from materials used in UNRWA schools.

A recently released report dated Febraury 2021, Review of UNRWA—Produced Study Materials in the Palestinian Territories, November 2020 to January 2021 echoing concerns raised over the years, reveals that UNRWA persists in using materials that incite hatred and violence against Israel. This issue is not confined to history and geography materials but extends to grammatical and mathematical exercises.
An organisation with such practices should no longer be permitted to misuse Australian taxpayer funding.
We have consistently cautioned that UNRWA schools, instead of guiding Palestinian children toward a brighter future, have hardened their hearts and exacerbated the Arab-Israeli conflict.

We therefore ask the House to while we appreciate the temporarily pause to the funding, the continuous revelations regarding UNRWA necessitate an immediate terminate the funding until the investigation is complete, and the results are transparently shared with the Australian public.
Until then, Australian taxpayers should not be expected to finance abroad what would never be tolerated at home.
from 68 citizens (Petition No. EN5901)
Skilled Migration Program

Immigration has been rejected SC 187 Regional skilled migration scheme in Dec 2017-2018 more than 2500 approximately applications & Nomination without asking further documents and most of the applicant received similar template which hasn't got clearly mentioned or genuine reasons of rejection its sounds like pre-planned mass rejected before home affairs abolished SC 457 & SC 187 changes implemented by the ruling administration 2018 now thousands of business went in liquidation and non resident families lost theirs employments and numbers increased on bridging visas struggling along with families to prove their nomination and visa applications in tribunal and ministial appeals
·Moreover the pendemic phase 2019-20222 was horrible breakdown our backbone struggled without any support by system.

· During we going through this my wife was pregnant we received refusal and then the stress level went high due to mentally stress we lost our unborn child in 2018-2019, Since then we trying to conceive but we not getting through due to we both are in extreme stress. Medical science has given up. We only hope to GOD but for our permanent residency of sc 187 we hope from current members to act as humans to serve justice.
Now currently our situation is getting worse day by day due to we literally broken financially,mentally,socially & emotionally.
We therefore ask the House to support a review of rejected Regional Sponsored Migration Scheme visa (subclass 187) applications from the period of December 2017—March 2018.
from 13 citizens (Petition No. EN5904)
E-Cigarettes and Vaping Products

The forthcoming Public Health (Tobacco and Other Products) legislation is oppressive and heavy-handed. Specifically, requiring vape users to obtain a prescription from Doctors who are apathetic or unwilling to provide assistance and forcing users to purchase from Government approved pharmacies.

This is an unreasonable and disproportionate response to concerns of youth uptake of tobacco products. The unreasonableness of these changes is particularly extraordinary in light of the ease of access of cigarettes from many Australian retailers such as Woolworths and Coles.

Research from several jurisdictions, both domestically and internationally have provided conclusive empirical data suggesting that vapouriser products are a safer alternative to cigarettes and tobacco smoke. For example, a systematic review of vape usage by England's Office for Health Improvement and Disparities has found that: "Vaping poses only a small fraction of the risks of smoking". Similarly, observational studies in Australia have concluded that vaping is associated with increased rates of quitting cigarettes (Chambers MS. Effect of vaping on past-year smoking cessation success of Australians in 2019-evidence from a national survey. Addiction. 2022;117(8)).

If implemented, the forthcoming legislation will force many 1000's of good-faith vape users to either submit to compulsory victimisation and doctor shopping in order to meet the bureaucratic regime of seeking alternatives to cigarettes, or otherwise seek illicit means to avoid cigarettes.

We therefore ask the House to repeal and review the terms of the proposed legislative changes to better focus on harm reduction and adopt new evidence-based, proportionate measures in response to youth-uptake of vaping.
from 28,679 citizens (Petition No. EN5905)
Skilled Migration Program
We, concerned business in regional Australia, are urging the Minister for Immigration and Citizenship to address severe processing delays for visa subclass 491.

Businesses in regional areas are finding it extremely difficult to fill the gaps when they require a skilled workforce. We have been advertising different roles for several months to hire skilled workers but has not had a single applicant.
This is a problem for all sectors in regional Australia, especially affecting the hospitality industry, tourism, aged care, and the construction industry as well.

The reason is clear; that there has been long delays in the processing of 491 visa which is causing acute depression and stress in the people who have invested life, money , study and their resources in Australia . Some people are waiting more than 2 years for the grant and their life is on hold as they can't marry, can't get a house or car loan as they need a permanent visa for that.

We therefore ask the House to take an action about this and ask the Minister for Immigration and Citizenship to urgently and immediately review visa 491 processing time, speed up the process and make new policies to support businesses across regional Australia.
from 1,144 citizens (Petition No. EN5906)
Defence Procurement: Submarines

Failure of a submarine's nuclear reactor core, by age, accident or attack, would cause radioactive poisoning of humans, animals, plant life, oceans and soils. Radioactive water would enter the water cycle including rainfall and river systems. Radioactive matter would travel long distances on ocean and air currents while dilution occurs. Local and migrating marine life would absorb radioactive matter entering the food chain of other marine animals and humans.

The useful life of a submarine's nuclear reactor core is estimated at up to 15 years. Disposal of used reactor cores remains an issue for countries such as the U.K., U.S.A. and Russia. How does the Australian Navy or Government plan to dispose of used reactor cores? The American Navy buries used reactor cores, is this solution acceptable to Australian citizens?

The half-life of uranium-235 is 700 million years, before becoming thorium-231 another radioactive material. The 20% uranium-235 concentration used in nuclear-powered submarines has this half-life. Disposal of used submarine reactor cores suggests a financial and environmental cost to be borne by current and future generations of Australians.

Recent technological advances and changes to military surveillance and peacekeeping requirements may quickly outpace the proposed response abilities of the nuclear-powered submarines ordered, rendering the submarines redundant before completion.
Paying financial break costs by cancelling the submarines is a justifiable financial and environmental gift to current and future Australians and neighbouring countries.
We therefore ask the House to investigate the cancellation of the order for nuclear-powered submarines and investigate nuclear-free technological alternatives.
from 42 citizens (Petition No. EN5907)
Consumer Protection

Joining fees, often levied without offering corresponding services or benefits, unfairly burden consumers without delivering value in return. They create barriers to entry, particularly for individuals with limited financial means, and contribute to inequitable practices in various sectors.

By prohibiting joining fees not linked to tangible services, Australia can uphold principles of fairness, transparency, and consumer protection, ensuring that citizens are not unduly burdened by unjustified financial obligations.

We therefore ask the House to introduce and pass a bill that explicitly prohibits the imposition of joining fees unless they are directly linked to the provision of services or benefits to consumers. Such legislation would ensure fairness, transparency, and consumer protection, safeguarding individuals from unjustified financial burdens.
from nine citizens (Petition No. EN5908)
Child Support Scheme

This petition is concerned with the Australian Child Support Scheme (CSS), and in particular the ways in which it currently used by some parents for financial abuse including coercive control of the other parent. Child Support payments are aligned with the percentage of time a child spends with each parent and so provides incentive for a parent to withhold children contrary to court orders or bonafide agreements.

Since previous review in 2006, evidence has been published confirming this method of relationship abuse. Published evidence demonstrates the damage forced removal of a parent from a child's life has on children and target parents.
The current method of calculating CS in conjunction with the government's current policy of ignoring court orders without substantive evidence, provides incentive for an offending parent to:
a) deny the target parent access to children,
b) access additional government financial support,
c) increase the CS liability of the target parent; and
d) make government complicit in this abuse.
Existing loopholes that facilitate financial abuse need urgent identification and rectification such as, inter alia:
1. For accountability and transparency, mandatory submission of:
- tax returns including all sources of revenue such as lump sum payments and income via trusts; and
- annual financial statements confirming child-related expenses.
2. Sudden changes of care be supported with Family Court Orders, or written agreement between both parents before any changes to CSS is made.
3. A pathway for 'fearful' parents to access CS safely.
We therefore ask the House to undertake urgent review of the CS legislation.
from 693 citizens (Petition No. EN5915)
Migration

The Australian has recently reported a notorious thallium poisoning case which occurred at Tsinghua University, China in 1994 but remains unsettled. As media reported, a main suspect lives in Australia while the victim Zhu Ling, the suspect's uni roommate, died after suffering seriously for about thirty years. A 2013 online White House petition on the whitehouse.gov website, demanding investigation and deportation of the suspect from the US, attracted more than 100,000 signatures in a few days and drew great attention from U.S. and Chinese mainstream media towards the cold case. It is alleged that following the White House petition, the suspect came to Australia with a different name and/or date of birth from her initial information registered in China. The suspect's probable presence in Australia may constitute a public interest concern in the Australian community.
We therefore ask the House to enquire into the reported poisoning case involving the suspect in Australia, including the following issues:
1) Has Australia granted to the suspect a protection visa, other visa, or Australian citizenship?
2) Has the suspect ever held two sets of identity, e.g. different names and different dates of birth?
3) Did the suspect disclose her full and truthful identity information to the immigration department in obtaining an Australian visa?
4) If fully informed, would the Minister be satisfied that the suspect passed the character test under s501 of the Migration Act 1958?
from 5,338 citizens (Petition No. EN5916)
Migration

Granting a bridging visa to contributory parent visa applicants in Australia is crucial to harness the positive impact of parents and grandparents in supporting their families and grandchildren. These applicants often play an integral role in childcare, providing emotional and financial support that contributes to the well-being of the entire family. A bridging visa ensures their continued presence, enabling them to actively participate in the upbringing of grandchildren and offering a stable support system. The bridging visa acknowledges the valuable contributions these individuals make to family life, emphasizing the importance of maintaining family unity and connections. It recognizes the potential for parents and grandparents to share cultural values, traditions, and wisdom with younger generations, fostering a sense of identity and belonging. Additionally, this visa facilitates financial assistance and stability, as many contributory parent visa applicants bring financial resources to support their families and invest in the local economy. Ultimately, granting a bridging visa aligns with Australia's commitment to family values, acknowledging the positive role parents and grandparents play in supporting and nurturing the next generation.

We therefore ask the House to consider streamlined processing for contributory parent visa applications, expediting the transition to bridging visas. Recognition of the significant contributions made by parents and grandparents in childcare and financial support is vital. Inclusive immigration policies should be developed to value family unity, enriching Australian society culturally and socially. Adopting a family-centric approach in visa processing acknowledges the crucial role played by parents and grandparents in nurturing younger generations.
from six citizens (Petition No. EN5920)

subdebateinfo.title: International Humanitarian Assistance: Occupied Palestinian Territories

p.span: International Humanitarian Assistance: Occupied Palestinian Territories

If the AVTOP scheme was activated for Australians impacted by the Hamas terrorist attacks on October 7, it should also be activiated for the Australians impacted by the genocide in Palestine that has been ongoing for the last 5 months. I think the severity of the situation in Palestine heavily outweighs the attack on October 7 and I think many Australians would agree. The people in Palestine have been bombed for 5 months straight, they have no food, no homes, no medicine, no clothing, no sanitary products and they have lost family members, limbs, parents and siblings. The people in Palestine have been attacked for 120 days straight what about the Australians impacted by this? If the goverment is going to offer financial assistance for Australians impacted by October 7 then it needs to offer Australians impacted by the genocide in Palestine, also financial assistance.
We therefore ask the House to offer Australians impacted by the genocide in Palestine, also financial assistance.
from 83 citizens (Petition No. EN5922)
Health Care: Medicinal Cannabis
The price of medicinal cannabis is beyond reach for the average person in Australia.
Most people living with chronic illnesses and chronic pain conditions have to spend a fortune on doctors, specialists and medications.
It leaves nothing left for things that we now know work like medicinal cannabis. Which can totally change a person's life. It can help people function again.
It helps with seizures, chronic pain, sleep, increases your appetite for people doing chemo (and other problems with food) among some many other benefits.
Most sick people can't work full time if at all, so how are they meant to afford upwards of $300 a month for a single medication that is proven to help in all these areas? On top of everything else.
The government needs to do something to bring down the price of medicinal cannabis, so that the average sick person can afford the treatment.
We are creating classes in our society by not allowing medication that helps to be readily accessible to everyone.
We therefore ask the House to reduce the price of medicinal cannabis so it can be accessible to everyone that needs it.
from 390 citizens (Petition No. EN5923)
Australian Curriculum

For many years evolution has been taught in our public schools. Over past 200 years science have been creating many theories about how the world and everything came about referring to their evolutionary theories. They have led the world to believe that there theories have been proven and the evidence is based on fact, which gave the the right to teach it as truth in our public schools.

But now the science today is saying other wise. Many well credited scientists are now saying that none of their theories are based on proven facts or can be observed. They just don't have any bases to teach that evolution is true. So if its being taught with a lack of true evidence how can it be taught at all. I would like to petition an inquiry into whether it is legal to teach it on the basis of deception.
We therefore ask the House to start an investigation into whether or not evolution is being taught in a legal context based on new science evidence.
from eight citizens (Petition No. EN5924)
Innovation Youth Centre

Our beloved Innovation Youth Centre, is facing a dire situation. IYC has been funded by the Attorney General's office for just two short years. Without an extension, over 500 struggling young people we help in the Whittlesea municipality will be left without support and a safe place to go. Without immediate financial support, it will close and cease its vital services effective March 1st 2024.

IYC has been a beacon of hope for many young individuals in our community, offering free support services that have made an immeasurable difference in their lives. It has provided them with a safe space where they can learn, grow and thrive amidst life's challenges.

According to the Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS), youth centres like ours play a crucial role in reducing crime rates among young people, providing them with constructive activities and positive role models (ABS 2019). They also contribute significantly towards improving mental health outcomes amongst our youth population (Australian Institute of Health and Welfare 2020).
Please sign this petition today to keep our youth centre open for those who need it most!

We therefore ask the House to support IYC with additional funding to help sustain our service, relieve the immense pressure on council organisations, reduce crime rates and help enhance the mental health and wellbeing of the next generation of Australia.
We cannot afford to lose this essential service that benefits not only our young people but also contributes positively towards community safety and wellbeing. We need your help now more than ever.
from 178 citizens (Petition No. EN5926)
Petitions received.
PETITIONS
Responses
Ms TEMPLEMAN (Macquarie) (10:02): I present the following 28 ministerial responses to petitions previously presented:
COVID-19: International Travel
Dear Ms Templeman

I refer to correspondence of 31 March 2022 to the former Minister for Immigration, Citizenship, Migrant Services and Multicultural Affairs enclosing Petition EN3869, with three signatures, concerning COVID-19 travel exemptions for the family of Australian temporary residents. I apologise for the delay in responding.

Australia's travel restriction policy played a key role in managing the impact of COVID-19 on public health in Australia, and was implemented on the advice of the Australian Health Protection Principal Committee.

Australia's border began to gradually re-open to international travellers from 1 November 2021, and from 4 July 2022 all remaining COVID travel restrictions were lifted-returning the Australian border to pre-COVID requirements.
The family members of Australian temporary residents can now return to Australia, regardless of their vaccination status, as long as they hold valid visas.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN3869 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Immigration, Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs, Mr Giles
COVID-19: International Travel
Dear Ms Templeman

I refer to correspondence of 31 March 2022, to the then Minister for Immigration, Citizenship, Migrant Services and Multicultural Affairs, enclosing Petition EN3927 with 28 signatures, concerning the inclusion of Bridging B (subclass 020) visas (BVBs) on the list of eligible visa holders that can travel freely without the need for an exemption from the COVID-19 related travel bans to enter Australia.

Bridging visas (BVs) allow the visa holder to stay lawfully in Australia while they are dealing with the Department of Home Affairs on a range of matters, such as waiting on the outcome of a visa application or review of a visa decision. A BV is not a substantive visa.

A BVB may be granted to a person in association with a substantive visa application, where they can demonstrate a substantial reason to depart and re-enter Australia during the processing of their substantive visa application and met other requirements. BVBs do not cease upon leaving Australia and allow the holder to travel outside of Australia and return within the specified travel period.

I can confirm that from 6 July 2022, travel restrictions were changed to allow all visa holders, including BVB holders, to travel to Australia without needing a travel exemption as long as they hold a valid visa and meet all other border entry requirements. Thank you for bringing Petition EN3927 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Immigration, Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs, Mr Giles
Overseas Students
Dear Ms Templeman

I refer to correspondence of 31 March 2022 to the former Minister for Immigration, Citizenship, Migrant Services and Multicultural Affairs, enclosing Petition EN3943, with seven signatures, concerning eligibility for the Temporary Graduate (subclass 485) visa (TGV). I apologise for the delay in responding.

The Australian Government welcomes international students and recognises the important contribution they make to Australian society. The Government set the Australian Study Requirement (ASR) to ensure that TGV applicants have the opportunity to forge links with communities, prospective employers and to become more familiar generally, with living in Australia.

While acknowledging that certain courses in isolation may not allow an applicant to meet the ASR, applicants can undertake packaged qualifications in order to do so. For example, a student could complete more than one qualification that results in a total of at least two academic years of study, resulting in an eligible qualification. Further information on the ASR is available on the Department of Home Affairs' website at: https://immi.homeaffairs.gov.au/visas/getting-a-visa/visa-Iisting/temporary-graduate- 485/australian-study-requirement.

There are also a range of other options for international graduates who may seek to remain in Australia via other temporary or permanent visas, subject to meeting eligibility criteria. Further information on other visa options is available at: https://immi.homeaffairs.gov.au/visas/getting- a-visa/visa-finder.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN3943 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Immigration, Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs, Mr Giles
Overseas Students
Dear Ms Templeman

Thank you for your correspondence of 7 November 2022 enclosing Petition EN4200, with four signatures, concerning reform/audit on the visa process with realistic and maintained timeframes while providing transparency on the visa timeframes and processing.

The Australian Government is committed to providing a world-leading immigration service. The Government announced $48.1 million over 12 months in the 2023-24 Budget to continue efforts to deliver improvements in the delivery of visa programs. Almost 600 new staff recruited between 1 July 2022 and 30 June 2023 are now supporting temporary and migration visa processing.
The Department of Home Affairs has cleared the temporary visa backlog and delivered a record Migration Program outcome:
The Department finalised almost 8.3 million visas in 2022-23, 190 per cent more than in 2021-22.
On-hand temporary visa applications decreased by 73 per cent from more than 600,000 on 30 June 2022 to just over 161,000 on 30 June 2023.

Visa processing times are available on the Department's website at: https://immi.homeaffairs.gov.au/visas/getting-a-visa/visa-processing-times/global- processing-times. Where possible, visa processing times are updated monthly, providing visa applicants with an indicative timeframe for processing applications.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN4200 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Immigration, Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs, Mr Giles
Skilled Migration Program
Dear Ms Templeman

Thank you for your correspondence of 7 November 2022 to the Hon Clare O'Neil MP, Minister for Home Affairs and Minister for Cyber Security, enclosing Petition EN4256, with one signature, concerning the designated regional areas in which Skilled Regional (Provisional) (subclass 489) visa holders must live, work and study.

The Australian Government recognises the important and valuable contribution regional visa holders, including subclass 489 visa holders, make in closing labour and skills gaps and supporting businesses and communities through their commitment to living, working and studying in regional areas of Australia while on a pathway to permanent residence.

The Skilled Regional (Provisional) (subclass 489) visa is for persons who are nominated by a state or territory government or sponsored by an eligible family member. Applications to the subclass 489 visa closed in November 2019.

This visa is subject to condition 8539 which requires the visa holder to live, study and work in an area specified by the Minister in an instrument in writing at the time the visa was granted. This condition does not restrict the visa holder to working solely in the postcode or designated regional area in which they reside. For example, visa holders may live in one designated regional area and work in another. They also have the flexibility to move and live and work in another designated regional area if they so choose.

The subclass 489 visa is one of the qualifying provisional visas for the permanent Skilled—Regional (subclass 887) visa. To be eligible for the subclass 887 visa, subclass 489 visa holders must, along with meeting other requirements, have lived for at least two years and worked full time for at least one year in a specified regional area. If granted, this visa allows holders to live and work anywhere in Australia.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN4256 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Immigration, Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs, Mr Giles
Energy
Dear Ms Templeman
Thank you for your correspondence of 7 November 2022 regarding petition number EN4301 on solar feed-in tariffs. I appreciate the time you have taken to bring this matter to my attention.

The retail electricity tariff customers pay and the solar tariff consumers receive for exporting solar differs due to a range of reasons. The electricity tariff retailers charge consumers is intended to recover a broader range of costs: the wholesale price (the costs of generating electricity); network costs (the cost to maintain and operate the poles and wires that deliver energy to and from their home); environmental costs and retailer costs.

The solar feed-in tariff is generally set to reflect the expected average wholesale electricity price only, which is the price the retailer would otherwise have to pay if it did not buy the surplus energy from customers with solar systems.

Wholesale prices vary over the course of the day. Growth in rooftop, and utility-scale, solar has increased supply of electricity during the day. This means that wholesale electricity prices are lower when solar exports happen, and this results in lower feed-in tariffs. The main benefit of installing rooftop solar is using what households generate during that day in their home and avoiding the cost of purchasing electricity at the retail price.

Each state and territory has different solar feed-in tariff rates and rules relating to solar tariffs. In jurisdictions where retail competition exists, retailers generally set solar feed-in tariffs to reflect a range of factors including their underlying cost base, their customers solar panel take- up rate and competitive considerations.

Electricity customers in New South Wales, Australian Capital Territory, South Australia, Tasmania and Queensland can compare a range of offers on the Australian Energy Regulator's Energy Made Easy website at www.energymadeeasy.gov.au. Customers living in Victoria can compare offers at www.compare.energy.vic.gov.au. Both websites are free to use and will provide customers with information on offers available in the market, making it easier for them to find the best deal.

It is important to note the deal with the best feed-in tariff may not be the best deal overall for a customer. A customer should consider an entire energy plan taking into account daily supply charges, feed-in tariffs and any variable charges against their own usage and solar exports to understand which offer best suits their needs.
Thank you for bringing the concerns of this petition to the government's attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Climate Change and Energy, Mr Bowen
Migration
Dear Ms Templeman

Thank you for your correspondence of 28 November 2022 enclosing petition EN4536 with 62 signatures requesting amendments to the Skilled Work Regional (Provisional) (subclass 491) visa. I appreciate the time you have taken to bring this matter to my attention.

The Australian Government recognises the important role Skilled Regional Provisional visa holders, including subclass 491 visa holders, play in supporting regional economies, employers and communities.

The subclass 491 visa is for applicants who are nominated by a state or territory government or sponsored by an eligible family member who is resident in regional Australia. Subclass 491 visa applicants have access to priority visa processing, eligible regional occupations and are eligible for Medicare and a clear pathway to permanent residence.

Subclass 491 visa holders who have lived and worked for at least three years in a designated regional area of Australia are eligible to apply for the Permanent Residence (Skilled Regional) subclass 191 visa which allows holders to live and work anywhere in Australia. This visa also provides access to those Government payments, services and benefits available to all Australian permanent residents.
Thank you for bringing this petition to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Immigration, Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs, Mr Giles
Human Rights: Iran
Dear Ms Templeman

Thank you for your correspondence of 28 November 2022 to the Minister for Home Affairs and Minister for Cyber Security, the Hon Claire O'Neil MP, enclosing Petition EN4544. Your correspondence has been referred to me as the matter falls within my portfolio responsibilities. I note that Petition EN4544 concerning current protests in Iran was recently presented in the House of Representative and gathered 69 signatures. I apologise for the delay in responding.

The petition requests the Australian Government to stop issuing or renewing visas for individuals linked to the Iranian regime. The Government continues to protect the Australian community from the risk of harm posed by non-citizens who engage in criminal conduct or behaviour of concern. Most permanent and temporary visas are subject to Public Interest Criteria (PIC) 4003(a) in the Migration Regulations 1994, which states that a visa held by a person whose presence in Australia is, or would be, contrary to Australia's foreign policy interests, may be cancelled.
Any cancellation would be dependent upon the Foreign Minister making a determination under PIC 4003(a).

The petition also requests that Iranian regime officials not find a safe haven for their assets or families in Australia. Consistent with the approach adopted by the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR), Australia prioritises the resettlement of those cohorts who have the greatest resettlement need. This focuses on:
people who are outside their home country and who have been assessed as refugees by the UNHCR and referred to Australia for resettlement
applicants proposed by a close family member who resides in Australia and

vulnerable cohorts within refugee populations who are outside their home country—this includes women and children, ethnic minorities, LGBTQI+ people and other identified minority groups who are referred by the UNHCR or proposed by a close family member in Australia.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN4544 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Immigration, Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs, Mr Giles
Migration
Dear Ms Templeman
Thank you for your correspondence of 28 November 2022 enclosing Petition EN4569, with 279 signatures, requesting amendments to the Skilled Work Regional (Provisional) (subclass 491) visa.

The Australian Government recognises the important role Skilled Regional Provisional visa holders, including subclass 491 visa holders, play in supporting regional economies, employers and communities.

The subclass 491 visa is for applicants who are nominated by a state or territory government or sponsored by an eligible family member who is resident in regional Australia. The subclass 491 visa has advantages compared to other skilled visas including priority visa processing, eligible regional occupations and more points for regional migration. Once granted, visa holders are eligible to enrol in Medicare and a clear pathway to permanent residence is available.

Subclass 491 visa holders who have lived and worked for at least three years in a designated regional area of Australia are eligible to apply for the Permanent Residence (Skilled Regional) (subclass 191) visa which allows holders to live and work anywhere in Australia. This visa also provides access to those Government payments, services and benefits available to Australian permanent residents.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN4569 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Immigration, Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs, Mr Giles
Migration
Dear Ms Templeman
Thank you for your correspondence of 8 February 2023 enclosing Petition EN4579, with 804 signatures, concerning Low Skill Temporary Migration for Bangladeshi Agricultural and Cleaning Workers.

The Australian Government understands and values the important role that the horticulture industry and skilled migrants play in contributing to Australia's economy. The Government is committed to assisting businesses fill labour shortages where Australian workers are not available. The Pacific Australia Labour Mobility (PALM) scheme continues to be the priority source of temporary migrant workers for Australia's critical sectors.

The PALM scheme remains a key program for meeting agricultural workforce shortages and allows eligible Australian employers to hire employees from nine Pacific Island countries and Timor-Leste. More than 35,000 workers are currently in Australia, with many thousands of pre-screened workers awaiting job offers. While the PALM scheme is an important part of this picture, it is just one of a broader set of solutions.

In addition to the PALM scheme there are a number of visa programs, including industry specific labour agreements to assist employers fill a range of skilled occupations in regional Australia where labour shortages exist. These programs are available to all nationalities including citizens of Bangladesh. Information on these visa programs and working in Australia is available on the Department of Home Affairs' website at: http://immi.homeaffairs .gov.au/visas/getting-a-visa/visa-finder/work.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN4579 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Immigration, Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs, Mr Giles
Asylum Seekers
Dear Ms Templeman

Thank you for your correspondence of 6 February 2023 enclosing Petition EN4612, with 225 signatures, concerning study and work rights equity for asylum seekers. I apologise for the delay in responding.

A Bridging visa (BV) is a temporary visa that may be granted in certain circumstances. There are multiple BV subclasses, the type of BV granted and the conditions imposed depends on the applicant's specific circumstances. A person's ability to work while in Australia as a BV holder will be determined by the visa conditions that are imposed on their BV at the time of grant. In most cases, BV "A", "B" or "C" subclasses that are typically granted in association with permanent visa applications do not have any conditions attached to them, allowing those BV holders to study and work without any restrictions.

A Bridging E visa (BVE), is one of the several classes of BV, it allows a person to stay in Australia lawfully for a temporary period of time, while they make arrangements to depart, finalise their immigration matter or await an immigration decision, such as a visa application or judicial review process.

The conditions imposed on BVEs are applied in accordance with the Migration Regulations 1994 (the Regulations). Certain conditions are mandatory and must be imposed by operation of law. Other conditions are discretionary and may be imposed if the delegate is satisfied it is consistent with the purpose of the visa gra nt (there are different BVE 'grounds' under the Regulations—for example BVEs may be granted on what is referred to as 'merits review', 'judicial review', 'Ministerial intervention' or 'departure' grounds—amongst others) and also taking into consideration the individual circumstances of the applicant. The Regulations and Departmental policies act as accountability and consistency safeguards when attaching conditions to a BV.

The 'no work' BVE condition must be imposed in certain circumstances, and in certain circumstances must not be imposed, as stipulated by Regulations. In a limited number of situations where the 'no work' condition is mandatorily imposed, the Regulations provide that a BVE holder may apply for a further BVE in order to have the 'no work' condition removed if they can demonstrate a 'compelling need to work' (based around financial hardship considerations). BVE holders granted in association with an ongoing protection visa applications, would additionally need to demonstrate that there was an 'acceptable reason for delay' in applying for their protection visa, to obtain permission to work. Lastly, there are other circumstances such as BVEs granted on 'departure' grounds, where the 'no work' condition is discretionary from the outset.

Unauthorised Maritime Arrivals (UMA), including transitory persons, are generally granted BVEs with work rights while their immigration status is being resolved. For BVE holders who are seeking merits or judicial review of a refused Protection visa application (this group are primarily non-UMAs) will generally have permission to work if they had work rights on their last substantive visa held.
The 'no study' BVE condition is a discretionary condition (regardless of circumstances). Under current operational policy the 'no study' condition is not imposed on BVEs granted for minors.

It is open to BVE holders to contact a Departmental Status Resolution Officer (SRO), who can explain their visa conditions and/or options. SROs can also help in referring BVE holders to other support services as required.
Further information on how to contact a Departmental SRO is available on the Department's website at: https://immi.homeaffairs.gov.au/what-we-do/status-resolution-service.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN4612 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Immigration, Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs, Mr Giles
Skilled Migration
Dear Ms Templeman
I refer to your correspondence of 22 May 2023 enclosing Petition EN4987, concerning language testing for Australian education and training graduates. I apologise for the delay in responding.

I respect the time taken by the Principal Petitioner to bring these issues to the Australian Government's attention. I would also like to acknowledge and thank the 1,212 individuals who took the time to sign it.

The Australian Government is committed to using English language requirements in migration legislation as a means to effectively manage immigration risk and ensure visa holders can participate fully in the Australian community.

I note the petition would like to see changes made to the Skilled visa requirement, exempting non-citizens who have studied at an Australian university or obtained professional registration from sitting an approved English test as part of the visa process.

The Department of Home Affairs implements Australia's non-discriminatory universal visa system. All non-citizens must have a valid visa to come to Australia or to remain living and working in Australia. Australia's Skilled Migration program is designed to attract migrants who make a significant contribution to the Australian economy, and fill skilled positions where limited Australian workers are available.

The English language tests prescribed in migration law for visa purposes continues to be the most reliable way for the Department to assess an applicant's English language proficiency and participation in the community as a skilled migrant.

While there are no immediate plans to make changes relating to the issues raised in petition number EN4987, I have asked the Department to consider this petition in the context of any future policy reforms that may occur in relation to English language testing at a time in the future.
Thank you bring Petition EN4987 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Immigration, Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs, Mr Giles
AUKUS
Dear Ms Templeman
Thank you for your correspondence of 11 September 2023 presenting Petition EN5246—Withdrawal from AUKUS. I have given careful consideration to the matters raised in the petition.

The Albanese Government recognises that the first responsibility of a government is to provide for the safety and security of its people. The AUKUS partnership is a core pillar of the Albanese Government's national security policy to protect our nation, its interests and security. We confront the most challenging strategic circumstances since the Second World War, and we do so at a time where Australia's economic connection with the world has never been greater.

This was at the core of the Defence Strategic Review and the Government's response, delivered in April 2023, which recognised that we must invest in our defence capabilities now: to defend Australia; deter through denial any attempt to project force against Australia; and protect Australia's economic connection to our region and the world.

The Albanese Government also recognises that we must contribute to the collective security of the Indo-Pacific because our security and prosperity depend on the stability and security of our region. Yet we need to contend with the reality that our region is witnessing the largest conventional military build-up the world has seen in decades. We do not question the right of countries to invest in and develop defence capabilities, but this must be done transparently and with strategic reassurance. We need to ensure the Indo-Pacific remains a region where all countries-big or small-are able to act in their sovereign interests to shape their own future free from coercion.

The acquisition of conventionally-armed, nuclear-powered submarines will enable Australia to better contribute to a sovereign and resilient Indo-Pacific and to deter aggression more effectively. For a maritime trading nation like Australia maintaining a submarine capability advantage over potential adversaries is vital. Closing or blocking sea lanes would have a devastating impact on Australia's economy and security; and of partners in South East Asia, the Pacific, and globally. By investing in these high-end capabilities, Australia is contributing to a more stable, secure and prosperous region.

We recognise the investment in Australia's conventionally-armed, nuclear-powered submarine program is significant. This will be one of the greatest industrial endeavours Australia has ever undertaken, supporting industry, jobs and infrastructure over decades. It is critical Defence expenditure is used to maximum effect and represents value for money. The Government will establish an independent monitor to provide assurance and advice across the breadth of work to implement Australia's conventionally-armed, nuclear-powered submarine program. Through the work of the independent monitor, there will be greater confidence issues are raised, considered and actioned.
Thank you again for forwarding the Petition EN5246 for my consideration.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Defence, Mr Marles
Nuclear Energy
Dear Chair

Thank you for your correspondence of 16 October 2023 regarding petition EN5360 to develop a fusion energy industry in Australia. I appreciate the time you have taken to bring this matter to my attention.

The Australian Government has committed to reducing emissions to 43 percent below 2005 levels by 2030 and to net zero by 2050. Nuclear fusion remains an experimental technology and if it is ever developed to the point of commercialisation, it will be developed and commercialised too slowly to help Australia meet these targets. The International Atomic Energy Agency, for example, reports that the construction and operation of demonstration electricity-producing fusion power plants could occur by 2050, depending on funding and technical advancement.

The draft GenCost 2023-24 Report, prepared by the CSIRO and the Australian Energy Market Operator, shows that renewables are the cheapest form of generation for Australia, even when additional costs for storage and new transmission are included. Renewable technologies are quicker to build and between 4 and 7 times cheaper to operate than nuclear power facilities.

The legislative prohibition on the approval of nuclear power plants under the Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act 1999 does not differentiate between nuclear technologies. The Australian Government has no plans to change the longstanding moratorium on nuclear power in Australia, or the laws which prohibit its deployment.
Thank you for bringing the concerns of this petition to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Climate Change and Energy, Mr Bowen

Migration
Dear Ms Templeman

Thank you for your correspondence of 16 October 2023 enclosing Petition EN5447, with 11,147 signatures, concerning visa options for parents of Australian citizen children under 18 to stay in Australia permanently.

The Australian Government acknowledges the important role family migration plays in allowing Australian citizens and permanent residents to reunite with their family members, delivering social outcomes for Australia and contributing to social cohesion by strengthening family and community bonds in Australia.

The Family stream of Australia's Permanent Migration Program seeks to facilitate the reunification of family members, including partners, children and parents, of Australian citizens, permanent residents and Eligible New Zealand citizens.

The permanent Parent visa program within the Family stream consists of Contributory and non-Contributory visa subclasses. It contains special provisions that enable parents of Australian citizen minor children to apply for a permanent Parent visa. These require that a relative, guardian or community organisation sponsor a parent on behalf of a person who is under 18 years of age.
The Government is aware of concerns related to the Visa Application Charge and processing times for Parent visas.

The Visa Application Charge for Parent visas only partially offset the cost of Parent migrants to the Budget, noting that Parent migrants draw upon government services over the span of their lifetime in Australia.

Processing times for permanent Parent visa applications are impacted by a range of factors, including the number of places allocated to a program each year within the broader migration program and the level of demand. High volumes of permanent Parent visa application lodgements, which for a number of years exceeded annual migration planning levels, have impacted on processing times for permanent Parent visas.

On 27 April 2023, the Minister for Home Affairs and Minister for Cyber Security, the Hon Clare O'Neil MP, released an outline of the Government's proposed migration strategy 'A Migration System for a More Prosperous and Secure Australia.' It maps the Government's approach for a better targeted, more efficient and outcomes-focused migration system, and notes the need for a reform of the Family program. The Migration Strategy is being developed and will be released at a later date.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN5447 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Immigration, Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs, Mr Giles
Skilled Migration Program
Dear Ms Templeman

Thank you for your correspondence of 4 December 2023 enclosing Petition EN5459, with 11 signatures to the Hon Clare O'Neil, Minister for Home Affairs and Minister for Cyber Security, concerning processing of Skilled Independent visas (subclass 189) and Skilled Nominated visas (subclass 190). Your correspondence has been referred to me as the matter falls within my portfolio responsibilities. I apologise for the delay in responding.

Reducing the number of on-hand visa applications, including in the subclass 189 and 190 caseloads, has been a priority for the Australian Government. The Department of Home Affairs has been undertaking a range of measures to reduce the processing times for this type of application, and additional resources have been assigned to visa processing.

Under the current Ministerial Direction, the highest priority for general skilled migration applications is being afforded to those visa applications made in relation to healthcare or teaching occupations. Subclass 189 and subclass 190 visa applications that are not made in relation to these specific occupations are given lower priority, and these applications are generally processed in the order in which they were received.

Each application is unique, however, and each is required to meet the eligibility criteria contained in Australia's migration legislation, before a visa can be granted. The time taken to process an application varies depending on a range of circumstances, such as the complexity of the application or whether additional checks and further assessment is required. Some delays in processing are experienced due to character and security checks, along with verification of an applicant's claims. Some applications are also prioritised ahead of others, due to compelling or compassionate reasons.

Currently, 90 per cent of subclass 189 and subclass 190 applications are processed within 12 months. The Department continues to process these applications efficiently, with the intention to further reduce the total number of applications on-hand.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN5459 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Immigration, Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs, Mr Giles
Skilled Migration Program
